channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [PDFBOX-1435] text is obscured by the Images
item.description: text is obscured by the Images,and Images is showed in reversed color.
item.summary: text is obscured by the Images

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: The inverted colors are gone in the current trunk (see attachment). I guess the text issue is related to PDFBOX-490

There seems to be an issue when creating the general path for the glyphs as a NPE is thrown:

java.lang.NullPointerException

I get an NPE too. The cause is that the point array starts with two !onCurve and !endOfContour elements, this results in lastCtrlPoint being null.

Points:
Point(85,-47,,)
Point(64,-55,,)
Point(44,-48,,)
Point(35,-33,,)
Point(36,-14,,)
Point(52,2,,)
Point(72,2,,)
Point(87,-8,,)
Point(92,-27,,endOfContour)
Point(64,-3,,)
Point(44,-14,,)
Point(44,-36,,)
Point(62,-48,,)
Point(82,-38,,)
Point(83,-15,,endOfContour)

to facilitate debugging, consider adding this in the Point class:

@Override
public String toString()

{ return String.format ("Point(%d,%d,%s,%s)", x, y, onCurve?"onCurve":"", endOfContour?"endOfContour":""); }

I get the effect "text is obscured by the Images,and Images is showed in reversed color" if I extract the embedded images first, with code like in processResources() in ExtractImages.java. The effect is related to PNG images only (PDPixelMap), and goes away if the PNG image isn't cached, by not assigning the variable "image" at the end of PDPixelMap.getRGBImage(). Thus there must be a difference in the image depending whether it is built before or within RenderUtil.convertToImage(). I haven't researched what the difference is.

PS: While the two attached files were created with "my" version, I just retested with a clean 2.0 trunk version, the effect also happens.
Partially inverted image I get if I extract embedded PNGs first
related effect, this time vertical bars visible at the left of the image when pngs are extracted first. The cloud.pdf file is from another jira.

About the NPE "issue when creating the general path for the glyphs" - I looked at the spec for truetrype

http://www.truetype-typography.com/ttoutln.htm

"Glyphs are defined as a series of contours, each of which contains three or more points. Each point is either on-curve or off-curve. Contours can even consist entirely of off-curve points."

So its not a font error, and my workaround is not the solution so I deleted it. The current implementation can't handle contours that consist entirely of off-curve points. It also can't handle fonts that begin with an off-curve point.

I searched for another implementation and found this one from Sun:
https://svn.atlassian.com/svn/public/atlassian/vendor/pdf-renderer/trunk/src/main/java/com/sun/pdfview/font/TTFFont.java
I used it to see the correct commands (moveto, lineto, quadto).

Based on these, I can't find an quick fix to get the current code to work. (I did try)

The Sun implementation renders the "problem glyph" in the chinese document correctly: a hollow bullet at the bottom right.

The code is based on the Sun code but modified. It is shorter and simpler than the current code. The original code has a LGPL license. I understand that the GPL license can't be used ( https://www.apache.org/licenses/GPL-compatibility.html ), but the LGPL license seems to be more friendly.
Code that renders glyphs even when they start with off-curve points
Image rendered with modified code, note the hollow bullet at the lower right.

@Tilman, thanks for your investigantions, but I'm afraid that we can't use that code because of the LGPL license, see [1] for further information

http://www.apache.org/legal/resolved#category-x

I'll try to find another solution, maybe your workaround and your findings are a good starting point.

I tried again today... I was able to fix the existing code by making four different changes.

However I noticed that one "O" from another file (the one from PDFBOX-940, third page, "Oobian") looks like it was beaten up. A test with a "clean" version shows the same problem, a test with the Sun rendering doesn't. I will look into it if I have the time. I suspect that a reason could be that quadto() is sometimes called with interpolated values for the control point, while Sun always calls quad() with a control point value from the array.

Another broken glyph is in the file of this jira, it is the fourth from the left. The "hook" on the chinese sign looks "unclean" even at 300dpi.

Anyway, I was able to fix that too, I only had to change the block that handles two off-curve points.

I'll upload the code later today, will render a few pages first.

Patch of the off-curve points bug fixes for rendering TT fonts. Decide for yourself if you want to delete the debug log entries. Plus rendered image, should hopefully look exactly like the one I uploaded yesterday which was using the "forbidden" LGPL Sun code.

I fixed the issue with the inverted pixelmaps in revision 1527349. PDFBox always chached the image version without a possible image mask.
Tilman thanks for your help and the effort, that nut wasn't easy to crack.

Update because this was missing: my patch of 29.9.2013 was committed as [ https://svn.apache.org/r1527359 ] by Andreas on 29.9.2013.

Original Batik contour code:
https://svn.apache.org/viewvc/xmlgraphics/batik/trunk/sources/org/apache/batik/svggen/font/SVGFont.java?view=markup
